table-wrap.caption: value of cumulative oil production, average oil production rate of single well, pressure trend (reflection of connectivity), aquifer energy for each pilot

formatted-caption.caption-text: value of cumulative oil production, average oil production rate of single well, pressure trend (reflection of connectivity), aquifer energy for each pilot

tr.th: Average cum. Oil production per well

tr.td: Depletion pressure follows the same trend, good connectivity

table-wrap.anchoringText: After determined well pattern and well spacing, 2 perforation strategies are proposed for our discussion. The strategy A is commingled production (perforating all intervals in both injectors and producers), and the strategy B is to only produce one member each time from the bottom to the top. Both of the 2 options have their advantages and disadvantages are listed in Table 2.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Comparison between different completion strategies

tr.td:
1. Expose the possible problems and conflict
2. Timely data acquisition
3. Higher productivity

1. Not easy to monitor the behavior of each member
2. Possible poor performance of water injection due to inter-member heterogeneity and interference

1. Easier to conduct surveillance
2. Better understand each member
3. Control the water cut and inject water at high efficiency

1. Timing consuming
2. Productivity of one member may not be able to achieve expected rate to satisfy the overall development plan
